source.name: City of Indianapolis Department of Public Works
source.notes: Based on City of Indianapolis recycling guidelines. Curbside recycling is currently subscription-based and varies by waste district. Universal curbside service planned for 2028.

materials.name: Newspapers
instructions: Place loose in recycling cart (if you have curbside service)
Keep dry
Inserts and ads can stay inside
notes: Indianapolis curbside recycling is subscription-based — check if your district has service
Universal curbside recycling is planned for 2028
commonMistakes: Don't recycle wet or moldy newspapers
Don't bag in plastic bags

materials.name: Magazines, catalogs, and brochures
instructions: Place in recycling cart
Glossy paper is accepted
No need to remove staples or subscription cards
notes: All printed glossy paper is accepted where recycling service is available
commonMistakes: Don't bag in plastic bags
Don't include wet or soiled magazines

materials.name: Junk mail and envelopes
instructions: Place in recycling cart
Window envelopes are accepted — no need to remove the plastic window
notes: Staples and paper clips are removed during processing
commonMistakes: Don't include padded/bubble mailers — those go in trash

materials.name: Cardboard boxes
instructions: Flatten all boxes
Remove packing materials inside
Place in or next to recycling cart
notes: Cardboard is highly valuable for recycling
Flatten to save space in your cart
commonMistakes: Don't include cardboard soaked with grease or food
Don't leave packing materials inside
Don't include wax-coated cardboard

materials.name: Milk cartons and frozen food boxes
instructions: Empty and rinse
Flatten frozen food boxes
Place in recycling cart
notes: Both refrigerated and shelf-stable cartons are accepted in Indianapolis recycling
Frozen food boxes are a specific accepted item
commonMistakes: Don't include juice pouches (Capri Sun) — those go in trash

materials.name: Plastic bottles and jugs (#1 PET)
instructions: Empty and rinse
Keep lids on or discard — both are acceptable
Place in recycling cart
notes: #1 PET is one of the most commonly recycled plastics
Indianapolis accepts #1 plastics in curbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with significant residue
Don't bag recyclables in plastic bags

materials.name: Plastic bottles and jugs (#2 HDPE)
instructions: Empty and rinse
Keep lids on or discard
Place in recycling cart
notes: #2 HDPE is one of the most valuable recycled plastics
Commonly found in detergent, milk, and shampoo containers
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with significant residue
Don't bag recyclables

materials.name: Plastic containers (#5 PP)
instructions: Empty and rinse
Place in recycling cart
notes: #5 PP is accepted in Indianapolis curbside recycling
Commonly found in food tubs and deli containers
commonMistakes: Don't include containers with food residue

materials.name: Aluminum cans
instructions: Empty and rinse
Leave the tab on — aluminum tabs stay on
Place in recycling cart
notes: Aluminum is infinitely recyclable
Indianapolis specifically notes that aluminum tabs should stay on cans
commonMistakes: Don't remove the tab — it stays on the can
Don't crush cans — leave intact for sorting

materials.name: Food cans (steel/tin)
instructions: Empty and rinse
Labels can stay on
Place in recycling cart
notes: Steel and tin cans are accepted in Indianapolis recycling
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food residue

materials.name: Scrap metal
instructions: Small pieces: place in recycling cart
Large pieces: take to a scrap metal recycler
Separate ferrous (magnetic) from non-ferrous for best value at scrap yards
notes: Indianapolis lists scrap metal as an accepted recyclable
Scrap metal recyclers pay for large quantities
commonMistakes: Don't include items with mixed materials (e.g., metal with attached plastic)
Don't include sharp metal without wrapping for safety

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
instructions: Empty and rinse
Remove metal lids
Place in recycling cart
Note: glass acceptance varies by location in Indianapolis
notes: Glass recycling varies by waste district and provider in Indianapolis
Check with your specific recycling provider about glass acceptance
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass — wrap and place in trash
Don't include window glass, mirrors, or ceramics
Confirm your provider accepts glass — not all do in Indianapolis

materials.name: Cereal boxes and paperboard
instructions: Flatten the box
Remove plastic liners or bags inside
Place in recycling cart
notes: Thin paperboard is recyclable
Paper pieces must be larger than a credit card to be captured by sorting equipment
commonMistakes: Don't include the inner plastic bag/liner
Don't include boxes heavily soiled with food

materials.name: Paper (office, printer, notebook)
instructions: Place in recycling cart
Paper must be larger than a credit card
Shredded paper: bag in a paper bag
notes: Indianapolis specifies paper pieces must be larger than a credit card for effective sorting
commonMistakes: Don't include tiny paper scraps — they fall through screens
Don't include wet or soiled paper

materials.name: Paper bags
instructions: Flatten and place in recycling cart
Can be used to contain shredded paper
notes: Paper bags are recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't include bags contaminated with grease or food

materials.name: Empty aerosol cans
instructions: Must be completely empty
Remove plastic cap
Do not puncture
Place in recycling cart
notes: Only completely empty aerosol cans are accepted
commonMistakes: Don't recycle aerosol cans with remaining contents
Don't puncture cans

materials.name: Clean aluminum foil
instructions: Must be clean — no food residue
Ball up small pieces to at least golf-ball size
Place in recycling cart
notes: Only clean foil is recyclable — contaminated foil goes in trash
commonMistakes: Don't recycle greasy or food-covered foil
Don't put small scraps loose — ball them up

materials.name: Plastic bags, wraps, and film
instructions: Place in trash cart
Many Kroger and Meijer stores accept clean bags for recycling
Never place in recycling cart
notes: Plastic bags tangle in sorting machinery and shut down facilities
They are the #1 contaminant in recycling
commonMistakes: NEVER bag recyclables in plastic bags — put items loose in the cart
Don't put any plastic film in recycling

materials.name: Styrofoam / polystyrene foam
instructions: Place in trash cart
Not recyclable in Indianapolis curbside programs
notes: Expanded polystyrene foam is not accepted in recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put any styrofoam in the recycling cart

materials.name: Food waste and scraps
instructions: Place in trash cart
Bag food waste to contain odor
Indianapolis does not offer curbside composting
notes: No curbside composting is available in Indianapolis
Consider home composting for fruit and vegetable scraps
commonMistakes: Never put food waste in recycling

materials.name: Fruit and vegetable scraps
instructions: Place in trash cart
Ideal for home composting
notes: No curbside composting in Indianapolis
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling cart

materials.name: Coffee grounds and tea bags
instructions: Place in trash cart
Excellent for home composting
notes: No curbside composting in Indianapolis
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Meat, bones, and dairy waste
instructions: Wrap in newspaper to contain odor
Place in trash cart
Put out on collection day to minimize pest attraction
notes: Meat and dairy attract pests — wrap securely
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling
Don't home compost meat or dairy — attracts rodents

materials.name: Diapers and hygiene products
instructions: Roll up and secure with tabs
Place in trash cart
notes: Diapers contain mixed materials and human waste — never recyclable
commonMistakes: Never put diapers in the recycling cart

materials.name: Candy wrappers, chip bags, and snack pouches
instructions: Place in trash cart
Multi-layer film packaging is not recyclable
notes: Despite the metallic appearance, these are multi-layer plastic film
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling — the metallic look is deceiving

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups
instructions: Place in trash cart
The polyethylene lining prevents recycling
Cardboard sleeve can be recycled separately
notes: Paper cups have a plastic lining that makes them non-recyclable
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling
The cardboard sleeve IS recyclable — separate it

materials.name: Soiled or wet paper and cardboard
instructions: Place in trash cart
Grease and food residue ruin paper recycling
notes: Even a small amount of grease can contaminate a batch of recycled paper
commonMistakes: Don't recycle greasy pizza boxes
Tear off the clean top to recycle if possible

materials.name: Plastic utensils and straws
instructions: Place in trash cart
Too small for sorting equipment
notes: Even though made of recyclable plastic types, these are too small for machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Bubble wrap, air pillows, and packing peanuts
instructions: Deflate air pillows
Place in trash cart
Some stores accept clean bubble wrap with plastic bag recycling
notes: Packing materials are not accepted in Indianapolis curbside recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in the recycling cart

materials.name: Paper towels, napkins, and tissues
instructions: Place in trash cart
Paper fibers too short and contaminated to recycle
notes: Used paper towels absorb moisture and contaminants
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Receipts (thermal paper)
instructions: Place in trash cart
Thermal paper contains BPA/BPS
notes: Thermal paper chemicals contaminate recycled paper products
commonMistakes: Don't recycle receipts

materials.name: Mirrors, window glass, and ceramics
instructions: Wrap carefully for safety
Place in trash cart
notes: Different chemical composition than bottle glass — different melting points
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling
Don't confuse drinking glasses with recyclable glass bottles

materials.name: Hangers
instructions: Place in trash cart
Return wire hangers to dry cleaners for reuse
notes: Hangers tangle in recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put any type of hanger in recycling

materials.name: Wax paper and parchment paper
instructions: Place in trash cart
Wax coating prevents recycling
notes: Wax-coated paper cannot be processed at paper mills
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Fast food wrappers and containers
instructions: Place in trash cart
Grease contamination makes these non-recyclable
notes: Most fast food packaging is contaminated with food and grease
commonMistakes: Don't recycle greasy food packaging

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: If wearable, donate to Goodwill, Salvation Army, or local thrift stores
If not wearable, place in trash cart
notes: Indianapolis does not accept textiles in curbside recycling
Donation is always preferred
commonMistakes: Don't put clothing in the recycling cart

materials.name: Rubber items
instructions: Place in trash cart
Garden hoses: cut into short sections
notes: Rubber tangles in recycling machinery
commonMistakes: Don't put rubber in recycling — especially hoses

materials.name: Juice pouches and drink pouches
instructions: Place in trash cart
Multi-layer packaging cannot be recycled
notes: Pouches are fused layers of plastic and metal
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with recyclable cartons

materials.name: Pizza boxes
instructions: Greasy portions go in trash
Clean top: tear off and recycle
Greasy bottom always goes in trash
notes: Grease-saturated cardboard fibers cannot be recycled
commonMistakes: Don't recycle greasy parts

materials.name: Incandescent and LED light bulbs
instructions: Wrap in paper or original packaging
Place in trash cart
notes: Incandescent and LED bulbs are not hazardous (unlike CFLs)
commonMistakes: Don't confuse with CFL bulbs — CFLs contain mercury

materials.name: Pens, markers, and tape
instructions: Place in trash cart
Mixed materials cannot be separated
notes: Too small and made of bonded materials for recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Indianapolis offers seasonal curbside yard waste collection
Place in approved paper bags or containers during collection season
Outside collection season: bag and place in trash
Branches must be bundled (4 feet max)
notes: Yard waste collection is seasonal — check indy.gov for dates
Not accepted in recycling carts
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling cart
Don't use plastic bags for yard waste during collection season

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Do not place in trash or recycling
Take to a household hazardous waste collection event
Home Depot, Lowe's, and Best Buy accept batteries
Car batteries: return to auto parts store
notes: Lithium batteries cause fires in trash trucks and recycling facilities
Indianapolis has periodic HHW collection events
commonMistakes: NEVER put lithium batteries in trash — fire risk
Don't put any batteries in the recycling cart

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Latex paint: dry out with kitty litter, then trash the solid
Oil-based paint: take to HHW collection
Never pour paint down drains
Check indy.gov for ToxDrop locations and events
notes: Indianapolis runs ToxDrop events for household hazardous waste
Dried latex paint can go in regular trash
commonMistakes: Never pour paint down drains
Don't put liquid paint in trash

materials.name: Motor oil and antifreeze
instructions: Take to auto parts stores (AutoZone, O'Reilly) for recycling
Or bring to a ToxDrop event
Never pour down drains or on the ground
notes: Used motor oil is re-refined into new oil
commonMistakes: Never pour down drains or storm drains
Don't mix motor oil with other fluids

materials.name: Pesticides, herbicides, and household chemicals
instructions: Take to Indianapolis ToxDrop event or permanent location
Keep in original containers with labels
Never pour down drains or storm drains
notes: Indianapolis ToxDrop is the primary disposal path for hazardous materials
commonMistakes: Never pour chemicals down drains
Don't mix different chemicals

materials.name: Fluorescent bulbs and CFLs
instructions: Take to Home Depot or Lowe's for free CFL recycling
Or bring to a ToxDrop event
Handle carefully — contains mercury
notes: Mercury makes fluorescent bulbs hazardous waste
If broken, ventilate area and follow EPA cleanup guidelines
commonMistakes: Don't put in trash — mercury is hazardous
Don't break bulbs

materials.name: Propane tanks and compressed gas
instructions: Do not place in trash or recycling
Large tanks: exchange at hardware stores
Small cylinders: bring to ToxDrop
notes: Pressurized containers can explode in compactor trucks
commonMistakes: NEVER place in trash or recycling — explosion risk

materials.name: Medications and pharmaceuticals
instructions: Take to a pharmacy drug take-back program
Indianapolis Metropolitan Police has medication drop-off boxes
Do not flush medications
Do not place in trash
notes: Flushing medications contaminates Indianapolis water supply
commonMistakes: Don't flush medications
Don't put in regular trash

materials.name: Sharps and needles
instructions: Place in an FDA-cleared sharps container
When full, take to an approved drop-off location
Never place loose sharps in trash or recycling
notes: Loose needles endanger sanitation workers
commonMistakes: NEVER put loose needles in trash or recycling

materials.name: Electronics / e-waste
instructions: Do not place in trash or recycling carts
Best Buy accepts most small electronics for free
Check indy.gov for e-waste recycling locations
notes: E-waste contains both hazardous materials and valuable metals
commonMistakes: Don't put electronics in curbside carts
Remove batteries before recycling

materials.name: Televisions and monitors
instructions: Do not place in trash or recycling
Best Buy accepts TVs up to 32 inches for free
Contact Indianapolis DPW for large item disposal options
notes: CRT TVs contain lead; LCD screens may contain mercury
commonMistakes: Don't leave TVs at the curb
Don't break screens

materials.name: Computers and laptops
instructions: Wipe personal data before recycling
Best Buy and Staples accept computers
Some nonprofits accept working computers
notes: Erase hard drives for privacy before recycling
commonMistakes: Don't forget to wipe personal data

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Take to a tire retailer — most accept old tires with new purchase
Check Indianapolis DPW for tire disposal options
notes: Tires are banned from Indiana landfills
Illegally dumped tires breed mosquitoes
commonMistakes: Don't leave tires at the curb
Don't illegally dump tires

materials.name: Large appliances
instructions: Schedule a heavy trash pickup with Indianapolis DPW
Appliance retailers often offer haul-away with delivery
Scrap metal recyclers may accept large appliances
notes: Appliances with refrigerants require special handling
Indianapolis offers heavy trash pickup for residents
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling
Don't remove refrigerant yourself

materials.name: Mattresses and large furniture
instructions: Schedule a heavy trash pickup with Indianapolis DPW
Donate usable items to Goodwill, Habitat ReStore, or Salvation Army
notes: Indianapolis offers heavy trash pickup — check indy.gov for schedule and rules
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling

materials.name: Cooking oil and grease
instructions: Small amounts: absorb with paper towels and trash
Large amounts: store in sealed container and take to recycling center
Never pour down drains
notes: Cooking oil causes sewer blockages and can be recycled into biodiesel
commonMistakes: NEVER pour cooking oil down the drain

materials.name: Books
instructions: Donate books in good condition to Indianapolis Public Library or thrift stores
Damaged books: remove hardcovers and recycle the paper pages
Place pages in recycling cart
notes: Paper pages are recyclable; hardcovers have mixed materials
Donation is always preferred
commonMistakes: Don't throw away books that could be donated

materials.name: Shredded paper
instructions: Place in a paper bag and fold or staple closed
Place the bag in recycling cart
notes: Loose shredded paper jams machinery and blows away
commonMistakes: Don't put loose shredded paper in the cart
Don't use a plastic bag

materials.name: Medical waste (non-sharp)
instructions: Place in trash cart (non-sharp items)
Sharps require special handling — see sharps entry
notes: Non-sharp medical waste goes in regular trash
commonMistakes: Never put loose sharps in trash
Never put medical waste in recycling

recycle: Newspapers, magazines, junk mail, envelopes, brochures
Milk cartons and frozen food boxes
Glass bottles and jars (varies by location)
Cereal boxes and paperboard (flatten, remove liners)
Office paper, notebook paper (larger than credit card)
Books (donate if possible, or recycle pages)
trash: Food waste and scraps (no curbside composting)
Candy wrappers, chip bags, snack pouches

recycle: Plastic bags — they jam sorting machinery
Mirrors, window glass, ceramics, drinking glasses
Paper smaller than a credit card

tips: Recycling is currently subscription-based in Indianapolis — check with your waste district
Universal curbside recycling is planned for 2028
Empty, rinse, and dry all recyclables before placing in the cart
Keep lids on or discard — both are acceptable in Indianapolis
Flatten cardboard boxes to save space
Aluminum tabs stay on the cans
Paper pieces must be larger than a credit card
Never bag recyclables in plastic bags — place items loose in the cart
Plastic bags are the #1 contaminant — take to Kroger or Meijer for recycling
When in doubt, throw it out — contamination hurts the recycling stream
Check indy.gov/activity/recycling for your waste district's specific rules
Indianapolis ToxDrop events handle hazardous waste — check schedule at indy.gov

locations.name: Indianapolis ToxDrop - Permanent Location
locations.hours: Check indy.gov for current hours and seasonal ToxDrop events
locations.notes: Indianapolis DPW operates ToxDrop for household hazardous waste. Multiple seasonal events throughout the year at various locations.

locations.name: Indianapolis Department of Public Works
locations.notes: Call for heavy trash pickup scheduling and recycling questions

locations.name: South Side Landfill (Citizens Transfer Station)
locations.notes: Fees apply. Operated by the City of Indianapolis.
